choices.description: If you are running on x86/Intel hardware.

sequence.title: Conda: Installation
sequence.description: Conda is an open-source package management system and environment management system that runs on Windows, macOS, and Linux. Conda quickly installs, runs, and updates packages and their dependencies. Conda easily creates, saves, loads, and switches between environments on your local computer. It was created for Python programs but it can package and distribute software for any language.

sequence.title: Choose a Conda Installation Method
sequence.description: Conda is an open-source package management system and environment management system that runs on Windows, macOS, and Linux. It was created for Python programs but it can package and distribute software for any language.

choices.title: Install Miniconda
choices.description: Miniconda is a free minimal installer for conda. It is a small, bootstrap version of Anaconda that includes only conda, Python, the packages they depend on, and a small number of other useful packages, including pip, zlib and a few others. [See if Miniconda is right for you.](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/install/download.html#anaconda-or-miniconda)

sequence.group: x86####POWER8 and POWER9####AWS Graviton2/ARM64####IBM z/Linux and LinuxONE

choices.title: Install Anaconda

sequence.title: Update your PATH to include conda

sequence.body:
conda activate
pip uninstall grpcio
conda install grpcio
pip install ray

sequence.title: Install Ray on a Kubernetes Cluster
sequence.description: This will install Ray on a Kubernetes context of your choosing.

sequence.body:
helm -n ray install example-cluster --create-namespace https://github.com/ray-project/ray/tree/master/deploy/charts/ray/
kubectl wait --for=condition=available --all rayclusters

graph.group: Example: Using Ray Tasks to Parallelize a Function####Example: Using Ray Actors to Parallelize a Class####Example: Creating and Transforming Datasets
graph.title: Run a Ray Job

sequence.title: Ray Core: Parallelizing Functions with Ray Tasks
sequence.description: First, you import Ray and and initialize it with `ray.init()`. Then you decorate your function with `@ray.remote` to declare that you want to run this function remotely. Lastly, you call that function with `.remote()` instead of calling it normally. This remote call yields a future, a so-called Ray object reference, that you can then fetch with `ray.get`.

sequence.body:
import ray
ray.init()

@ray.remote
def f(x):
    return x * x

futures = [f.remote(i) for i in range(4)]
print(ray.get(futures)) # [0, 1, 4, 9]

choices.title: Example: Using Ray Tasks to Parallelize a Function
choices.description: First, you import Ray and and initialize it with `ray.init()`. Then you decorate your function with `@ray.remote` to declare that you want to run this function remotely. Lastly, you call that function with `.remote()` instead of calling it normally. This remote call yields a future, a so-called Ray object reference, that you can then fetch with `ray.get`.

sequence.title: Ray Core: Parallelizing Classes with Ray Actors
sequence.description: Ray provides actors to allow you to parallelize an instance of a class in Python or Java. When you instantiate a class that is a Ray actor, Ray will start a remote instance of that class in the cluster. This actor can then execute remote method calls and maintain its own internal state.

choices.title: Example: Using Ray Actors to Parallelize a Class
choices.description: Ray provides actors to allow you to parallelize an instance of a class in Python or Java. When you instantiate a class that is a Ray actor, Ray will start a remote instance of that class in the cluster. This actor can then execute remote method calls and maintain its own internal state.

sequence.title: Install Ray Data
sequence.description: Ray Datasets are the standard way to load and exchange data in Ray libraries and applications. They provide basic distributed data transformations such as `map`, `filter`, and `repartition`, and are compatible with a variety of file formats, data sources, and distributed frameworks.

sequence.title: Install Ray Data
sequence.description: Ray Datasets are the standard way to load and exchange data in Ray libraries and applications. They provide basic distributed data transformations such as `map`, `filter`, and `repartition`, and are compatible with a variety of file formats, data sources, and distributed frameworks.

sequence.group: New Dataset from Range####New Dataset from File
sequence.title: Creating and Transforming Datasets

sequence.body:
import ray

# Create a Dataset of Python objects.
ds = ray.data.range(10000)
# -> Dataset(num_blocks=200, num_rows=10000, schema=<class 'int'>)

ds.take(5)
# -> [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

ds.count()
# -> 10000

# Create a Dataset of Arrow records.
ds = ray.data.from_items([{"col1": i, "col2": str(i)} for i in range(10000)])
# -> Dataset(num_blocks=200, num_rows=10000, schema={col1: int64, col2: string})

ds.show(5)
# -> {'col1': 0, 'col2': '0'}
# -> {'col1': 1, 'col2': '1'}
# -> {'col1': 2, 'col2': '2'}
# -> {'col1': 3, 'col2': '3'}
# -> {'col1': 4, 'col2': '4'}

ds.schema()
# -> col1: int64
# -> col2: string

choices.title: New Dataset from Range
choices.description: Get started by creating Datasets from synthetic data using

sequence.body:
import ray
import pandas as pd
import dask.dataframe as dd

# Create a Dataset from a list of Pandas DataFrame objects.
pdf = pd.DataFrame({"one": [1, 2, 3], "two": ["a", "b", "c"]})
ds = ray.data.from_pandas([pdf])

# Create a Dataset from a Dask-on-Ray DataFrame.
dask_df = dd.from_pandas(pdf, npartitions=10)
ds = ray.data.from_dask(dask_df)

# Transform the dataset using .map()
ds = ray.data.range(10000)
ds = ds.map(lambda x: x * 2)
# -> Map Progress: 100%|| 200/200 [00:00<00:00, 1123.54it/s]
# -> Dataset(num_blocks=200, num_rows=10000, schema=<class 'int'>)
ds.take(5)
# -> [0, 2, 4, 6, 8]

# Transform the dataset using .filter()
ds.filter(lambda x: x > 5).take(5)
# -> Map Progress: 100%|| 200/200 [00:00<00:00, 1859.63it/s]
# -> [6, 8, 10, 12, 14]

# Transform the dataset using .flat_map()
ds.flat_map(lambda x: [x, -x]).take(5)
# -> Map Progress: 100%|| 200/200 [00:00<00:00, 1568.10it/s]
# -> [0, 0, 2, -2, 4]

choices.title: New Dataset from File
choices.description:
Datasets can be created from files on local disk or remote datasources
such as S3. Any filesystem [supported by pyarrow](http://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/generated/pyarrow.fs.FileSystem.html)
